pageContext.claim: “We have a Governor and uh, Attorney General, we have 25,000 people, wanna go in Minnesota right? One of the reasons we gonna win, and they want us to have 250 people, well that's a slight, you know, slight difference. We have 25,000 people, but they have a rule, you can't have more than 250 people for a political event, so they're scamming us.”
pageContext.analysis: There is no evidence this is the case. The 25,000 figure was a hope expressed by a manager for an outdoor rally at Dodge Center’s McNeilus Steel. But then the Trump campaign shifted the venue to Rochester, Minn. "Not content to adhere to the state’s limit of 250 people, Trump representatives searched for a more accommodating city and venue,"" the Twin Cities Pioneer Press reported. "Trump officials and GOP state leaders targeted state leaders, blaming the “free speech-stifling dictates” of [Gov. Tim] Walz and [Attorney General Keith] Ellison....But Ellison’s office said it did nothing to interfere with the event, only asking that McNeilus [the original venue] have a COVID-19 preparedness plan if it were to host the rally. Trump campaign officials’ beef appeared to be with Rochester city officials, who didn't want to see a super spreader event in their community."
